questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You need to recommend a solution for integrating luggage information.
What should you recommend? To answer, drag the appropriate types to the correct tables. Each type may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

comments.content: i thought the same. and for me it was not clear if 'new solution' means you replace the old and the old will then be decommissioned. Obviously, you don't want to see luggage from travels last year. so virtual table from one data verse to another data verse.

from a business point of view, i can immagine, that luggage traking (even though it sound simple huh?), can have very tricky edge cases and airport and aircraft industry is not an industry you can accept a broad tolerance of error. You need to cover them all and just adding an activity to track luggage on an airport sound to me dangerously simplistic.
but then live with redundancy in 2 systems ... ? better not!
But it also requires: "Minimize the use of third-party products and custom development." A custom activity has less development than Virtual Activity. Indeed, encourage the use of Dataverse.
and keeping passengers and their luggage in different systems is not the best idea
In the case, Luggage is in another App.

discussion.content:
Luggage - Virtual Table

"The company has a custom app for managing and tracking passenger luggage"
Even thought it says "The app uses Microsoft Dataverse", my understanding is that this is in anouther soulution/environment and our solution is for 
"You are hired to design a new solution to manage passenger information, reservations, and maintenance."

Anouther note that suggests our solution only needs read only access to the luggage table.
"Agents need to view which pieces of luggage match to each passenger, and then need to add the total on the passenger record."

comments.content: I dont understand why you said it cannot. It is an actual requirement that you have to be able to model relationships in Dataverse. If you have one, then you can get the count.

discussion.content:
Custom Table for both.

Luggage doesn't make sense be a Custom Activity and the specific requirement "Agents need to view which pieces of luggage match to each passenger, and then need to add the total on the passenger record." unfeasible the virtual entity.

See limitations: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powerapps/developer/data-platform/virtual-entities/get-started-ve

Virtual: because I can create the virtual table, create a relationship with the passenger records and allow the agents to see my luggage and do a count on the total. Where in the limitations does it say I cannot do this?

I do not understand the idea of a Custom Activity Table. Why would I need or want to create records in my system at all, when all I need to do is View the records and get a count and store the count in this system.

The luggage itself has already been captured and stored in a table owned by another App. So why would I be creating activity records in the new system related to the luggage or even custom records at all?

I assume there is a misspelling in the question. Since the answer refers to "customer table" which makes perfectly sense for the passenger.
With that misspelling in mind, "custom(er) table" does not match für luggage.

Answer is correct
Custom Activity table. Custom Table

The act of viewing luggage is the activity - it can include metatdata of the luggage.
Custom for both
correct!
Custom Table for both.
Luggage and Customer - this asked in MB600 too: https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/microsoft/view/32818-exam-mb-600-topic-7-question-1-discussion/

comments.content: However, if you look at the description of an activity table, it talks about activity tables including "data that helps determine what action the activity represents, for example, subject and description".. that might come in handy when talking about luggage, like what time did the luggage leave this airport and arrive at the next, what does it look like, do we still maintain control over it, etc.

>> The company has a custom app for managing and tracking passenger luggage. The app uses Microsoft Dataverse.

I think you are right.

discussion.content: Custom table for both

questions.answer_description:
Luggage: Custom activity table -
An activity can be thought of as any action for which an entry can be made on a calendar. An activity has time dimensions (start time, stop time, due date, and duration) that help determine when the action occurred or will occur. Activities also contain data that helps determine what action the activity represents, for example, subject and description.

Passenger: Customer table -
The account and contact tables in Microsoft Dataverse are essential for identifying and managing customers, selling products and services, and providing superior service to the customers. A customer address table is used to store address and shipping information for a customer.
Scenario: The company has a custom app for managing and tracking passenger luggage. The app uses Microsoft Dataverse.
Agents need to view which pieces of luggage match to each passenger, and then need to add the total on the passenger record.
Incorrect Answers:
✑ A virtual table is a custom table in Dataverse that has columns containing data from an external data source. Virtual tables appear in your app to users as regular table rows, but contain data that is sourced from an external database dynamically at runtime, such as an Azure SQL Database.

questions.question_text:
You need to recommend an authentication solution for the planned implementation of Dynamics 365.
What should you include in the recommendation?

choices.C: Create a new tenant for Dynamics 365 Customer Service.
choices.B: Use the Office 365 tenant for Dynamics 365 Customer Service.

discussion.content:
B. Use the Office 365 tenant for Dynamics 365 Customer Service.

"The company uses Microsoft Office 365."
"The company has a custom app for managing and tracking passenger luggage. - The app uses Microsoft Dataverse."

There is no mention of on-prem and by the above statement regarding the luggage system they are using Dataverse.
B is the correct answer!

Selected Answer: B
B is correct.

Selected Answer: B
I don't find any reference to on-premises services in the scenario.

Selected Answer: B
It is B.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct.

Selected Answer: B
They are already using O365. No mention of on-prem authentication.

Selected Answer: A
correct
This question was on the exam.

comments.content: Right, for me the correct is D: Federated Identities: available for more complex scenarios and provide scalability auth, ensures Single Sign On with all apps and to thousands of employees. It is a regional airlines enterprise with wide resources, network and systems, not a small private business with only a single MS Tenant!

nice idea but i don't see why the vendor sould access relecloud systems?

the only thing they need access to, could be done with portal/power pages
"Aircraft maintenance vendors must have only view and upload privileges to their invoices and receipts."
hmm view and privileges. in power pages they use the term list and privileges ... sort of access security is there too. weird!

discussion.content: D Surely? Aircraft are serviced by vendors - so this should be federated identities? Maintenance workers should not have direct access to D365 Customer Service (portal could be used).

I'm unsure about this one. The current environment suggests that they have many different systems, but nothing about on-prem is mentioned. Synchronized identity is designed to allow management of cloud users from on-prem AD, but it says they are already on Office 365..
A - "Ensure that employees can sign in to all Microsoft apps by using one set of credentials per employee"

choices.E: Copy the Customer Service Representative role.
choices.B: Add security to the Core Records and assign users to the Customer Service Representative role.
choices.C: Copy the Microsoft Dataverse Basic User role.
choices.D: Rename the Customer Service Representative role to Agents.
choices.A: Add security to the seat entity and assign users to the Agents role.

discussion.content:
I would say A,E,F instead of B,E,F for two reasons:
 -In requirements it is said "include a custom entity named seats and grant agents access to the entity" which is addresed by A but not by B answer
- If you have named your copied role "Agents" it makes no sense that later you assign users to another role

comments.content: I agree

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AEF
E
Copy the Customer Service Representative role.
 F
Name the new role Agents
 A
Add security to the seat entity and assign users to the Agents role

In that order.

AEF
but I confess that first i ruled A out because you add a priv. to a role for a given entity.
"Add security to the seat entity" -> sounds wrong
"assign users to the Agents role" -> sounds wrong again (in my perspective I assign a role to a user and NOT a user to a role.
finally the menue says APPLY not assign.
(What roles would you like to apply to the 1 User you have selected?)

Selected Answer: AEF
AEF so glad everyone agrees.

Selected Answer: AEF
AEF is correct..

Selected Answer: AEF
This is correct

Selected Answer: AEF
Agree with TheLadyB

Selected Answer: AEF
it should be AEF
This question was on the exam.
AEF as below
A, E, F - "The security rule for agents must contain the privileges in the default Customer Service Representative security role"

AFE
B is incorrect because it "assign users to the Customer Service Representative role." . It should assign the user to "Agent role" instead.
Agree with TheLadyB

questions.question_text:
You need to create an Agent security role.
Which three actions should you recommend? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

choices.A: one app for each job role
choices.C: one app for all employees of the team
choices.D: one app for each team of employees

questions.question_text:
You need to provide the IT team and managers with a mobile solution.
How many apps should you recommend?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Correct

comments.content: Best practice is to separate different functionality to groups of users.

And as you stated later in the comments - is one of the requirements ;-)
"Application use layout should be role specific"
I think you provided the most exact point

discussion.content:
A:
Requirements state "Application use layout should be role specific."

A: role specific yes, of course. but 'job role' not sure, is IT team a role? is management a role?
B: certainly not
C: "the team" singular. the question is for 2 Teams. i had some doubt
D. one app per Team: might be tempting but then you have the maintenance supervisor team, and the contracts team and then i realized: 'teams of employee' is not very specific. you can have teams unbounded of internal organisational structures such as task force teams, project teams.
This question is about picking the one which is not as wrong as all the others are. not about the right one. I go for A.

comments.content:
second thoughts. from organisational theory 'IT' is not a role but a function so is 'management'. Agents not sure, more a team. and 'contracts team' too. 'aircraft maintenance vendors', and more...

and job role sounds too low level granularity. if tomorrow they invent a new 'job role' like scrum master in the IT team and you stick 100% to a job role setup, you would have to create a scrum master app? it says EACH job role.


Application use layout should be role specific.

remains D?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A, this is better because in this case for C they said each "team". I dont want to make an assumption that there are only 2 teams, which if there WERE and only managers were in one and IT in the other then A = C, but since I dont know how many teams there are under IT People and Under Managers A != C so A

Selected Answer: A
Correct answer is A because the requirements are for Managers and the IT team to have different sitemaps, but it's not said that the IT team doesn't need access to the same things. You can only customize the sitemaps for different users by using separate apps for these users, so A - one app for each job role - is correct.

Selected Answer: A
I see the discussion is divided between A & C. Let me shed some light why A is a wise choice. 

Between options A and C, option A (one app for each job role) is the more appropriate choice. This is because creating an app for each job role allows for customization based on the specific needs and tasks of each role, such as IT staff and managers. This approach simplifies maintenance, updates, and training while providing a more efficient and user-friendly experience for employees.

Option C (one app for all employees of the team) might be easier to implement initially, but it may not address the unique needs and requirements of each job role as effectively as option A. By tailoring the app's features and layout to be role-specific, option A ensures that the solution meets the needs of both IT staff and managers while maintaining a manageable number of apps.
What is the correct answer

Selected Answer: C
Should be C

Selected Answer: A
Should be A

Selected Answer: C
Should be C

Agents - Microsoft Power Apps (They need an app that will have different features)
Management - Power BI(To make Informed decisions)

comments.content: True, with the assumption the Power Bi dashboard needed would be surfaced in said Power App.

discussion.content: Agents is PowerApps, Management is PowerBI

First I was also thinking about Power Apps and Power BI. But after reading:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/model-driven-apps/configure-interactive-experience-dashboards
"nteractive experience dashboards can be a one-stop workplace for app users, such as service reps, to see workload information and take action. They're fully configurable, security-role based, and deliver workload information across multiple streams in real time. Interactive dashboard users don't need to page through the application looking for a particular row; they can act on it directly from the dashboard."
I'll go with Dashboards and Power BI

A Power BI dashboard is a single page, often called a canvas, that tells a story through visualizations. 

and then you have the dynamics CRM Dashboard which are a collection of charts (you know these ugly old charts which are limited to only a tiny number of 5000 records and airports have more than 5000 by day). but in this case its the chart and not the dashboard which does the job.
but dashboard is a good answer as it is not specific for CRM nor PowerBi it could even be mixed. Who did write this question??!

comments.content: for full north america, gpt counts 23 countries such as Panama. But excludes Colombia and Venezuela which I would include in North America because it is northern of the equator.
correction chart limit is 50'000 records which is still exceeded if you define the north america region by the eqator line. airline / airport business is big data

discussion.content:
If it has said Model Driven App for agents it would have been easy as I dont like when they just say "Microsoft Power Apps" which means alot

Agents: MPS
Because the sheer volume of things they need will not be done purely but a dashboard, so you need a dashboard + model driven app (instead of canvas) so you can embed the dashboard and then have the app part do the other stuff

Management: Power BI

comments.content: I mean MPA (not MPS) sorry

discussion.content:
correct answers:
Dashboard
Power BI

"Agents need a solution to replace paper reservation checklists." which is done best by BPF.
Other requirements too can be done via Dashboard (Model Driven App)

Hence, Dashboard and PowerBI is answer.

comments.content: How do you think Agents will track reservation issues with a dashboard?

Since you can go directly from the dashboard to the relevant table rows the dashboard is the major tool for the agent.
PowerBI for management.

discussion.content: Given everything the agent needs, I believe the answer is correct.
IDK, agents need whole bunch of things.. Power Apps answer IMO suits better..

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You need to recommend tools for agents and management.
Which tools should you recommend? To answer, select the appropriate option in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Dashboard -
Agents need dashboards to show a current count of all reservations on the entity.

Box 2: Power BI -
Management requires paginated reports for stakeholders.
